Award.AwardTitle: Printing Embedded Sensors for Turbine Blades by Electro-spraying Polymer Derived Ceramics

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for the realization of a new technology for direct printing of low-profile ceramic sensors onto curved surfaces such as turbine blades. In the proposed process a liquid phase polymer precursor ink will be electrosprayed, cured, and pyrolyzed to yield a surface-conformed ceramic sensor element. To be amenable to printing, special consideration of the ink rheology and electrical conductivity is required. The research plan is a combination of experiments and modeling of the electrospray process with consideration of sensor functionality, device resolution and durability.

The research results could find broad use where surface conformance and low profile are needed for sensor applications in harsh environments such as power plants, nuclear reactors, coal mines and aircraft. The proposed printing method has the potential manufacturing advantages of being rapid and low-cost. The focus here will be on turbine blades and successful completion would enable real time, in situ thermal and mechanical measurements in turbines which operate at increasingly higher temperatures. Acquired data would enable enhanced engine control, health monitoring, and design optimization as well as contribute to improved efficiency and reliability during operation. Graduate students will be directly involved in the project and K-12 students will benefit from classroom demonstration of advanced printing process concepts.

Institution.Name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES, THE

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

Electrospray is an emerging liquid-atomization technique that is suitable for processing complex fluids and highly viscous liquids. In this project, we increase the viscosity of the PDC precursor to supress droplet spreading and rebound to achieve higher printing resolution as well as material utilization rate. We also systematically studied the instability of electrified micro-jets under transverse perturbation with an end goal of suppressing spray divergence for improved printing resolution. We successfully discovered and visualized that at proper perturbation frequencies, very clean jet breakup appear and no satellite droplets are generated. This significantly improves the monodispersity of the spray and increases printing resolution and accuracy. We also designed and characterized a new electrospray emitter based on ball-point pen, which greatly expands the operation envelope by about ten folds. The low cost, easy accessibility and wide selection of ballpoint pens make these promising electrospray emitters for solution based materials processing.

In this project, we also perform fundamental studies on PDCs, aiming at developing suitable materials for high-temperature sensor applications. We developed new PDC system -- SiAlCO, which is more inert to environments. We demonstrated that the material exhibits very large piezoresistivity and piezo-dielectricity. These properties make the material particularly suitable for sensor applications. We have also proposed mechanistic explanation for the observed behavior. We found that dielectric behavior of PDCs can be explained using Schottky double-layer model. The barrier height can be tailored by annealing temperature. 

The project has provided research opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students. The grant supports four graduate students (one female PhD student and one minority PhD student). Two REU students were also supported, including a veteran who served four years for US Marine Corp and deployed in Japan and Germany. He won the 1st place in Undergraduate Research Showcase at the University of Central Florida and went on getting a M.S. degree at UCF. Another REU student was accepted by the PhD. Program at Yale, largely due to his REU experience. Those students were trained in an interdisciplinary field of materials science and fluid dynamics. Work under this project has contributed to 13 journal articles.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2018
Modified by: Linan An

  • A novel approach for controlling the electrified jet breakup and generating strictly monodispersed droplets. This work was featured as cover article in Physical Review Letters.
